journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Research on the leakage and dynamic characteristics of a new kind of radial annular seal and comparisons with labyrinth seals

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control, Southeast University, Nanjing, People's Republic of China
2School of Energy and Power Engineering, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: WF Zhang, Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control, Ministry of Education, School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, Jiangsu Province, People's Republic of China. Email: zwf5202006@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © Yang Jian Gang 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: To minimize fluid leakage and improve rotordynamic stability of traditional seals, a new kind of radial annular seal is presented in this article. The structure and the sealing principle are analyzed. Compared to the traditional labyrinth seal, the fluid leakage direction is altered from the axial to radial direction. The flow resistance is increased, and the flow-induced force is reduced greatly. There is also a tremendous improvement in the wear resistance of the seal. Three-dimensional numerical models of the traditional labyrinth seal and radial annular seal are set up. Calculated results show that the discharge coefficient of the radial annular seal is about 20% lower than that of the labyrinth seal. Though the rotating speed has a small influence on the radial seal force for both the radial annular seal and labyrinth seal, it has a large effect on the tangential seal force. The tangential seal force increases with the increasing speed, and the destabilizing force in the radial annular seal is reduced greatly when compared to that in the labyrinth seal. The radial seal force of the radial annular seal is about 1.5–2.5 times as strong as that of the labyrinth seal. The tangential seal force is about 30–50% lower than that of the labyrinth seal under the same eccentricity, and this ratio becomes larger and larger with the increasing speed. Finally, the dependency of the seal characteristics on the design parameters is studied. It is shown that the optimum ratios of the clearance s to the tooth thickness b (s/b) for the outward and inward flows are 4.5–5.5 and 11–13, respectively. The flow characteristics perform best with the ratio of the seal chamber width B to the tooth height H (B/H) on the same order of 5.5–7 for the two kinds of flows.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Seals in turbomachinery are necessary components that are used to minimize working fluid leakage. Concerns have been raised on the efficiency improvement and vibration reduction for the improvement of turbine-operating parameters. To that end, many kinds of seals have been presented in the past years. Solving the contradiction between the seal leakage and wear resistance and improving the vibration-reduction ability is still a matter of concern.

Conventional labyrinth seals (LS) play an important role in preventing fluid leakage from high-pressure to low-pressure regions. However, it has also been considered as the primary cause for rotordynamic instabilities. Wachter and Benckert1 showed destabilizing effect of cross-coupled stiffness coefficients that were strongly tied to the preswirl of the gas entering the seal. More theoretical and experimental studies were carried out by Childs and Pelletti.2–4 Song5 presented a new model to predict the flow response in an axial turbine stage with a shrouded rotor. Wagner6 developed a test rig supplied with N2 for high pressures up to 25 MPa. The force that arose in the LS was considerably smaller than that of the honeycomb seal, and therefore better able to be kept under control. Hole-pattern, honeycomb, grooved, damper, brush, hybrid seal, etc. have later been designed in many applications in an effort to decrease the leakage and improve the rotordynamic stability. Yu7 presented that hole-pattern seal configurations generally provided higher effective damping than the honeycomb seals, and hole-pattern damper seals can be attractive alternatives to honeycomb seal. Picardo8 compared rotordynamic characteristics between tooth-on-stator LS and hole-pattern stator seal. Rotordynamic coefficients and leakage test results were presented by Childs9 for three grooved seals with helix angles of 0°, 15° and 30° against rotation. The results showed that increasing the helix angle yielded a progressive reduction in the cross-coupled stiffness coefficient and a progressive increase in leakage. Ertas10 determined frequency-dependent rotordynamic force coefficients for a new fully partitioned damper seal (FPDS). Meanwhile, a comparison was carried out with the conventional pocket damper seal (PDS). The tests showed that the FPDS design possessed much more positive direct damping and direct stiffness compared to the conventional PDS. Brush seals effectively controlled the leakage in air-breathing engines, albeit only applied for relatively low pressure differentials. Shoed and hybrid brush seals intended to overcome the main deficiencies found in conventional brush seals; such as excessive rotor and seal wear due to sustained contact between these two components, low pressure differential sealing capacity and unidirectional rotation. Experimental researches on the characteristics related to the brush seal have been presented in references.11–13

The above mentioned seals can be considered as the axial flow-type seals. They are composed of multiple axially spaced blades or surface patterns along the rotor axis that provide a restrictive path for the working fluid that impedes the leakage between the machine stages. For the axial seals, the seal rubbing often occurs between the stator and rotor, and it will lead to the bending of the rotor. Additionally, there are always abundant spiral flows along the flow path under the exertion of inlet preswirl and rotor surface speed. The spiral flow as well as circumferential flow in seal cavities induces a destabilizing force that is the main cause for flow-induced vibration. Paolillo14 presented a hammerhead seal to minimize the geometric design space needed for multiple knife-edged LSs. The hammerhead seal changed the flow direction, and the flow resistance was increased; however, the structure designs concentrated upon the modification of the hammerhead shape, and it was difficult to reduce the seal force for the increasing rotor surface area.

This article presents a new kind of radial annular seal (RAS) to reduce the seal leakage and improve the vibration reduction ability. The fluid leakage direction is altered from the axial to radial direction. The teeth of the seal are arranged along the radial direction, so the seal clearance changes in the direction perpendicular to the directions of rotor vibration. The wear resistance of the seal is improved. The fluid-induced force is also significantly reduced. Three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) method is employed to analyze the characteristics of the conventional LS and RAS. Comparisons are carried out between the two kinds of seals. The effects of clearance, pressure ratio and eccentric ratio are examined. Finally, the influence of the ratio of clearance to the tooth width as well as the ratio of the seal chamber width to the tooth height on the flow characteristics of the RAS is analyzed.

sec.title: Radial annular seal
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the specific structure of a single-stage RAS with six radial annular teeth (three on each side) and one axial tooth. Compared to the traditional seal, a seal disk is added and fixed on the rotor, spinning with the same speed. Several radial annular teeth are assembled on the two plates, and an axial tooth is installed in the seal housing. Figure 1.
Structure diagram of a single-stage radial annular seal.

Figure 2 shows the fluid flow in the RAS. We can see that the flow path is divided into the outward flow and the inward flow. The axial spiral flow line is cut off by the seal disk, and so the seal force acting on the rotor is mainly in the axial direction. Moreover, the concerned rotor vibration is in y- and z-direction, while the clearance of the RAS changes mainly in x-direction. The bending deformation of the rotor has an effect only on the axial tooth. Thus, the wear resistance of seals can be improved. Figure 2.
Schematic drawing of the fluid flow in the radial annular seal.

sec.title: Discharge coefficient
sec.p: The performance of a seal can be described by the relation between a flow parameter and the pressure ratio, clearance, and eccentric ratio, etc. The most common flow parameter is the discharge coefficient.15–18 It can be defined as follows (1)Cd=m·m·ideal where m· is the actual mass flow rate, and it can be obtained through experiments or numerical computations. m·ideal is the ideal mass flow rate.

In the case of isentropic flow condition, the ideal mass flow rate m·ideal is defined as follows (2)m·ideal=P02-Pn2RgT0∑i=1n1Ai2 where P0, Pn and T0 are the inlet total pressure, exit static pressure and inlet total temperature, respectively. Rg is the gas constant; n is the number of seal teeth; and Ai is the average flow area for the ith tooth.
The flow area is constant for the conventional LS, and it can be stated as follows (3)Ai=π(Rt2-Rr2) where Rt and Rr are the radius of tooth tip and rotor, respectively.
For the RAS, the flow area changes along the flow path, and it can be written as follows for the ith tooth (4)Ai=2πRis where Ri is the radius of the ith tooth, and s is the seal clearance.

sec.title: Seal force
sec.p: The nonuniform pressure distribution of the fluid in the seal cavity will generate a seal force that acts on the rotating rotor. The seal force can be divided into the radial force and the tangential force according to the eccentric direction of the rotor. The destabilizing tangential force has a significant effect on the system stability. The seal with smaller tangential force and larger radial force is the primary objective of seal design.

sec.title: Numerical model
sec.p: An advantage of using CFD is its capacity to analyze a large number of complex design configurations and parameters, and it makes no fundamental assumptions on geometry, shear stress at the wall, as well as internal flow structure. Therefore, the use of CFD analysis in many rotary machines has been increasing rapidly in recent years with the development of commercial software.19–25

In this article, Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes (RANS) CFD analysis of the seal is performed. The equations can be written in Cartesian tensor form as (5){∂ρ∂t+∂∂xi(ρφi)=0∂∂t(ρφi)+∂∂xj(ρφiφj)=-∂p∂xi+∂∂xj[μ(∂φi∂xj+∂φj∂xi-23δij∂φl∂xl)]+∂∂xj(-ρφ'iφ'j¯) where φi denotes a scalar such as velocity, pressure, energy, or species concentration (i=1, 2, 3).

The finite-volume-based method is used by the solver, and it solves the equations for conservation of mass, momentum, and energy in terms of the dependent variables, velocity and pressure. Three-dimensional computational grids for different seal geometries are generated. Figure 3 shows two-dimensional geometry for the two kinds of seals. The details of the seal dimensions are shown in Table. 1. This is designed in terms of the condition of our previous test rig.26 Figure 3.
Seal geometry.
Table 1.
Seal dimensions.
Number of teeth, n H (mm) B (mm) b (mm) s (mm) Rr (mm) Rd (mm) Eccentricity ratio, ɛ
7 5 13.5 1 0.2, 0.5, 0.8 90 135 0.25, 0.35, 0.50, 0.65, 0.75

Figure 4 shows the boundary conditions defined for the conventional LS and the RAS. The calculation assumes the fluid to be an ideal gas at constant temperature and the entire flow to be turbulent. Figure 4.
Schematic diagram of the computational grid.

Regarding modeling of turbulence, most researchers rely on the standard k–ɛ model with the wall-function approach.27 Numerically, this approach is very stable. However, from a physical point of view, it performs poorly in calculating flows with significant mean streamline curvature and secondary flows.20 Recently, the renormalization group (RNG) k–ɛ turbulence model, which is suitable to solve the problems of flow accompanied by separating or circulating flow, has been employed to analyze the seal performance by many researches.28–30 In this article, the RNG k–ɛ turbulence model is used for calculating the flow characteristics inside the seal. The momentum equations, the continuity equation and the turbulence model equations are solved using the simple pressure–velocity coupling algorithm. Second-order upwind discretization is employed for momentum equations, and the pressure is discretized with a second-order scheme. The near-wall treatment adopts the standard wall functions. The swirl is zero at the inlet. Pressure is specified at the inlet and outlet boundaries. A no-slip and an adiabatic boundary condition are imposed for the stator and the rotor. A 3D mesh is built for the analysis with eccentric rotor. The eccentricity of the rotor is 25–75% of the radial clearance. The study of mesh density is performed to investigate the effect of mesh density and also to know the extent of a sufficiently fine mesh required to capture the important flow physics. As shown in Figure 5, the process includes incremental adjustments to grid size until the leakage and fluid-induced force results become independent. As a result of this analysis, the total number of nodes for the LS and RAS is set to about 810,000 and 930,000, respectively. Near-wall values are checked for all cases to ensure that the mesh is appropriate for application of the wall functions. Values of the dimensionless wall distance (y+) for the LS and RAS lie between 36 and 220, 28 and 245, respectively, which is acceptable for the wall functions in this study. Figure 5.
Influence of the number of grid nodes.

sec.title: Validation of CFD model against the published literature results
sec.p:
This study focuses on the leakage characteristics and seal force in seals. To validate the simulation approach and solver settings, validation was carried out against our previous experimental work reported in the literature.26 The test rig and seal dimensions are shown in Figure 6. There are, in total, six sets of seals in the rig. To obtain the seal force, the impedance matrix of cylinder was first measured by using a shaker. The seal force can be obtained through multiplying the impedance matrix by the measured change in cylinder vibration at different inlet pressures. Figure 6.
Experimental setup: (a) general view of the rotor system and (b) dimensions for a set of seal.

Figure 7 shows CFD and experimental results of the seal force and mass flow rate for a specific clearance, eccentricity ratio and rotating speed. The error bars represent the uncertainty associated with experimental results. It can be seen that CFD model shows good prediction in seal force and mass flow rate. Meanwhile, the seal force and mass flow rate increase almost linearly with increasing pressure ratios. This verification shows reasonable prediction using CFD model. Figure 7.
Comparison of computational fluid dynamics and experimental results:(a) seal force vs. pressure ratio, (b) mass flow rate vs. pressure ratio.

sec.title: Leakage performance
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the convergence curves corresponding to variables through the computational process. The residuals of all variables are almost less than 1e-3 after 2500 iterations. Figure 9 shows the discharge coefficients Cd calculated from the numerical analysis for the LS and RAS. The discharge coefficients increase as the clearance increases for all the cases. As the pressure ratio Pr gets larger, the discharge coefficient decreases. Note that the discharge coefficient of the RAS is about 20% lower than that of the LS with the same clearance under identical conditions. Figures 10 and 11 show the pressure field and the velocity fields of the two kinds of seals for s = 0.2 mm, Pr = 2. It can be seen that the pressure drops down along the flow direction for both seals. For the RAS, there are four 90-degree turns along the flow path, and large vortex occurs under the exertion of the radial teeth and seal disk. The effect of resistance enhancement by turbulence is improved significantly. Figure 8.
Convergence curves of computational process: (a) residual convergence curve for labyrinth seal, (b) residual convergence curve for radial annular seal, (c) seal force convergence curve for labyrinth seal, (d) seal force convergence curve for radial annular seal, (e) convergence curve of inlet mass flow rate for labyrinth seal and (f) convergence curve of inlet mass flow rate for radial annular seal.
Figure 9.
Variation of discharge coefficients with pressure ratio for different clearances (ɛ=0.5).
Figure 10.
Pressure field for the two kinds of seals: (a) conventional labyrinth seal, (b) radial annular seal.
Figure 11.
Velocity field for the two kinds of seals: (a) entire domain of labyrinth seal, (b) local flow field of labyrinth seal, (c) entire domain of radial annular seal and (d) local flow field of radial annular seal.

sec.title: Seal force
sec.p:
Figures 12 and 13 illustrate the seal-force change versus rotating speed and eccentric ratio for s = 0.5 mm, Pr = 4. It can be seen that the rotating speed has greater influence on the tangential forces than that on the radial force due to the rotor surface speed. The tangential force increases almost linearly with the increasing speeds. From Figure 13, the radial force increases linearly with the increasing eccentric ratio as well as the tangential force. The radial force of the RAS is about 1.5–2.5 times as strong as that of the LS. The tangential force is about 30–50% smaller than that of the LS under the same eccentricity, and this ratio becomes significantly larger with the increasing speed. These consequences can be explained by the RAS design where the circumferential flow is reduced greatly, and the effect of spiral flows inside the seal is degraded substantially. Compared to the conventional axial seals, the numerical result also indicates a drawback of the RAS that it brings larger axial thrust due to the added seal disc. For s = 0.2 mm, e = 0.5, the axial thrust of the RAS is 29,689, 58,276 and 82,943 N corresponding to Pr = 2, 3 and 4, respectively, while the axial thrust of the LS approaches zero for the smooth rotor. However, the extra axial force of the RAS can be balanced by the thrust bearing in practice. Figure 12.
Variation of seal force with speed (ɛ=0.5).
Figure 13.
Variation of seal force with eccentricity ratio (n=9000 r/min).

sec.title: Flow behavior for the outward and inward flows in the radial annular seal
sec.p: The flow field inside the RAS is inherently quite complex due to its particular structure. The fluid flow area is not constant as that in the conventional LS, and it can be separated into two types of flows: outward flow and inward flow. As shown in Figures 1 and 2, the flow area becomes larger and larger for the outward flow, and vice versa for the inward flow. The effects of the design parameters for conventional seals have been analyzed as suggested in references.31–33 For the RAS, further research is needed to study the dependency of the seal characteristics on the design parameters.

Given the computation time, the inlet mass flow rate and the exit pressure are given, and the inlet total pressure is calculated for the case of the outward flow. While the mass flow rate is obtained for the inward flow under the given inlet and outlet pressure conditions, a higher inlet pressure and a lower mass flow rate are desirable for the outward and inward flows, respectively.

sec.title: Effects of the ratio of the clearances to the tooth thickness b
sec.p:
Figure 14 gives the influence of the ratio of the clearance s to the tooth thickness b (s/b) on the flow characteristics. We can see that the flow characteristics are sensitive to the smaller ratio of s/b, and the influence decreases with the increasing ratio, especially greater than 20. Note that there is a big discrepancy in the optimum ratio s/b between the outward and inward flows, and the optimum ratios of s/b for the outward and inward flows are 4.5–5.5 and 11–13, respectively. Thus, to achieve optimal sealing effect, the working clearance on the side of outward flow should be kept smaller than that on the side of inward flow under the same geometry of tooth. Figure 14.
Influence of the ratio s/b on the inward and outward flow characteristics.

sec.title: Effects of the ratio of the seal chamber width B to the tooth height H
sec.p:
Figure 15 shows the effect of the ratio of the seal chamber width B to the tooth height H (B/H) on the flow characteristics. There are two peaks of the ratio of B/H for each kind of flow; however, the flow characteristics perform best with the ratio of B/H of the same order of 5.5–7. In the case when the ratio B/H takes its value almost as 1, the sealing performance becomes bad, and this geometry should be avoided for the seal design in practice. Figure 15.
Influence of the ratio B/H on the inward and outward flow characteristics.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, a new type of RAS is presented. The fluid leakage direction is altered from the axial to the radial direction, and the teeth of seal are arranged along the radial direction. Thus, the seal clearance changes in the direction perpendicular to the directions of rotor vibration. The coupling effect between the rotor vibration and seal force weakens substantially. As a result, the wear resistance of the seal is also greatly improved.

A three-dimensional CFD simulation is employed to analyze the inherent characteristics of the conventional LS and RAS. Calculated results show that the discharge coefficient of the RAS is about 20% lower than that of the LS with the same clearance under identical conditions. The effect of resistance enhancement by turbulence is greatly improved for the new kind of RAS.

Calculated results also show that the rotating speed has significant influence on the tangential force and a lesser influence on the radial force. The tangential force increases almost linearly with the increasing speeds. The radial force of the RAS is about 1.5–2.5 times as strong as that of the LS. The tangential force is about 30–50% smaller than that of the LS under the same eccentricity, and this ratio becomes significantly larger with the increasing speed.

Finally, the dependency of the seal characteristics on the design parameters is further studied for the RAS. It is shown that the optimum ratios of s/b for the outward and inward flows are 4.5–5.5 and 11–13, respectively. The flow characteristics perform best with the ratio of B/H in the same order of 5.5–7 for both kinds of flows.

Though the results associated with this article are based on CFD method, the above conclusions are beneficial for the structural design of the RAS in future works, and experimental verification will also be presented in forthcoming research studies.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NO. 51275088) was sincerely acknowledged.
